tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: A psalm of David
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: earnestly
tn.text: "sincerely"

tn.ref: my soul thirsts for you, and my flesh longs for you
tn.text: These two clauses have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize how greatly the writer desires to be with God. AT: "my whole being greatly desires to be with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: dry and weary land
tn.text: "hot, dry desert"

tn.ref: my lips will praise you
tn.text: Here "my lips" represents the whole person. AT: "I will praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will lift up my hands in your name
tn.text: Here "in your name" means "to you." AT: "I will worship you and pray to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: It will be as if I ate a meal of marrow and fatness
tn.text: Here the writer speaks of knowing and worshiping God as being more satisfying than eating a good meal. AT: "I will be happier than a person who eats a meal of fat and choice food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: with joyful lips my mouth will praise you
tn.text: Here "with joyful lips my mouth" represents the whole person who will praise God joyfully. AT: "I will praise you joyfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: when I think about you on my bed ... in the night hours
tn.text: These two clauses have the same meaning. The ideas are repeated to emphasize how much the writer thinks about God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: in the shadow of your wings I rejoice
tn.text: The writer speaks of God as if he were a bird protecting its young under his wings. AT: "I rejoice because you protect me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I cling to you
tn.text: "I need you" or "I depend on you"

tn.ref: your right hand supports me
tn.text: Here, the right hand is used as a symbol of strength and power. AT: "you support me" or "you lift me up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will go down into the lowest parts of the earth
tn.text: This means they will die and go to the place of the dead. This can be stated clearly in the translation. AT: "will die and descend into the place of the dead" (UDB) or "will die and go down into the place of the dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: they will be given over to those whose hands use the sword
tn.text: Here "the sword" represents death in battle, and "those whose hands use the sword" refers to enemies who kill them in battle. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will cause them to die in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they will become food for the jackals
tn.text: Here "they" refers to the corpses of those who die in battle. AT: "jackals will eat their dead bodies" (See: [[: en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the jackals
tn.text: "jackals" are a kind of long-legged wild dog. They feed on carrion, game, and fruit.

tn.ref: the king
tn.text: David is speaking about himself. This can be stated clearly in the translation. AT: "I, the king of Israel," (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: swears by him ... proud of him
tn.text: The word "him" refers to "God."

tn.ref: but the mouth of those who speak lies will be stopped up
tn.text: Here "the mouth" represents the whole person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "but God will silence the liars" or "but God will silence those who lie" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
